conclusion: Analyze the motion of the system before and after the string breaks.
The system consists of two objects, A and B, connected by a string passing over a pulley. The mass of each object is m = 1 kg, and the angle of the inclined plane is θ = 37°.
The height of object A is h = 1 m.
Object A is at a height of 1 m above the ground, and object B is at the bottom of the inclined plane.
The forces acting on object A are its weight mg and the tension in the string T.
The forces acting on object B are its weight mg sin θ and the normal force N from the inclined plane.
The normal force N is balanced by the component of the weight of B perpendicular to the plane, so N = mg cos θ.
The equation of motion for object A is mg - T = ma_A.
The equation of motion for object B is mg sin θ - T = ma_B.
Since the string is massless and the pulley is frictionless, the tension T is the same on both sides of the pulley.
The accelerations of A and B are related by the length of the string.
The time t it takes for A to hit the ground is the time it takes for the string to be fully unwound, so h = 1/2 a_A t^2.
Solving for t, we get t = sqrt(2h/a_A).
The acceleration of A is a_A and the acceleration of B is a_B = a_A sin θ.
The distance traveled by B is s_B = 2h^2 sin θ/a_A.
When A hits the ground, the string is fully unwound, so the distance traveled by B is (L - h)/sin θ.
Solving for a_A, we get a_A = 2h^2 sin^2 θ/(L - h).
The time t_A for A to hit the ground is t_A = sqrt((L - h)/sin^2 θ).
The velocity of A when it hits the ground is v_A = 2h sin θ/sqrt(L - h).
The velocity of B is v_B = 2h sin^2 θ/sqrt(L - h).
